title: Robots Unlocking Secrets Of The Ocean
text:
Sponsored By Robots Unlocking Secrets Of The Ocean Robots covered in a range of different sensors and cameras are used to tell us more about the bottom of the ocean. 17:42, UK, Friday 04 September 2015 Play video "Swipe: Robots Take To The Seas" Video: Swipe: Robots Take To The Seas Share by email By Angela Barnes, Sky News Robotic vehicles are helping scientists discover why certain areas of the marine environment are particularly attractive to predators like whales and dolphins. 
In this week's Swipe, the team visit the National Oceanography Centre (NOC) in Southampton, where technology is being developed to help monitor the ocean. 
Last month, working in partnership with the World Wide Fund for Nature, NOC deployed an Autonomous Surface Vehicle, nicknamed Thomas. 
It is from Milford Haven in Wales and it's tasked with studying aquatic mammals and sea birds. 
A submarine glider has also been deployed in the Celtic Sea - an area of the Atlantic to the south of Ireland, bordered in the northeast by St George's Channel and in the east by the Bristol Channel and English Channel - to help Thomas monitor activity. 
Head of Marine Policy for WWF, Dr Lyndsey Dodds, said: "The area, the Celtic Deep area, that the robots are heading to, is quite an interesting one because there are different water masses there and all of that means it makes it a very productive area. So you get some of these top predators, things like marine mammals, whales and dolphins. 
"These robots will be collecting continuous data there, and that's something you can only get through this sort of technology, alternatives would be research ships, which tend to just take moments of information rather than a long-time series through using this type of technology." 
To capture information, the robots are covered in a range of different sensors and cameras. 
Thomas has marine acoustic monitors on board to pick up any underwater noises of marine mammals communicating. 
The submarine glider, also known as a Slowcum, is equipped with sensors capable of measuring the water temperature and acoustic 'pingers' to detect plankton and shoals of fish. 
Southampton-based marine scientist, Lavinia Suberg, said she hopes the technology will help them discover much more about marine life. 
"Thomas is fitted with sensors that provide us with information mainly on the surface of the water column, whereas the underwater submarine provides us with information on the water column itself - the physical characteristics and productivity. 
"We then combine this information with the purpose of finding biodiversity hotspots in the ocean. What we want to find out is: are there certain areas that are particularly diverse and if so, why." 
The three-week mission is expected to end later this month. 
However, the smart vehicle has the ability to harvest solar and wind energy, meaning it could potentially remain offshore, delving into the depths for answers, for several months yet. Promoted Stories
